docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Rick Renzi, a freshman Republican, voted for the new Medicare prescription drug benefit, billed by Republican leaders as a boon to the elderly. But Mr. Renzi has not found throngs of grateful constituents expressing gratitude. On the contrary, Mr. Renzi said, after a town hall meeting here, ''I hear lots of honest concern about the unknown, and there's fear in the unknown.'' For example, he said, voters want to know if the drug benefit is truly voluntary, or if they will have to drop coverage they already have to get it.

headline.main: In Arizona, Unease Over New Medicare Drug Law

docs.abstract: Republican Arizona Rep Rick Renzi finds confusion and skepticism among constituents about new Medicare prescription drug benefit; was initially opposed to plan, but backed it in end; says now it was good first step, but he favors allowing imports of low-cost prescription drugs from abroad; those knowledgeable about new law believe it may help low-income people, but doubt they will benefit personally; many others simply do not understand complex provisions of law; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicaid, a joint state-federal health insurance program for the poor, has blossomed into the largest and most expensive public health program in the nation. For the most part, this is a blessing. Medicaid provides badly needed health care to those who can least afford it as well as badly needed financial support for the health institutions that take care of them. It is fast expanding into the nation's imperfect substitute for universal health insurance. But the states are having serious trouble carrying their share of the costs. When a recession hits, as in recent years, state tax receipts plunge and the ranks of the poor expand, putting enormous strain on state budgets. Unlike Washington, most states are compelled by law to balance their budgets every year, and the soaring state costs for Medicaid have to compete with other programs, particularly education. States find that cutting Medicaid is especially painful as it means losing some federal matching funds, a loss of $1 to $3 for every state dollar saved.
docs.abstract: Editorial holds that Medicaid has blossomed into largest and most expensive public health program in US; contends that Bush administration has proposed transforming Medicaid into something that looks suspiciously like block grant that is intended to cap federal expenditures in future years; maintains that could force states to trim their programs drastically, leaving millions of needy people without coverage; proposes adjusting federal matching formulas so states are not forced to cut Medicaid just when it is most needed; holds that relentless rise of health care costs is real problem, and until that issue is addressed, any serious attempts to curb Medicaid costs will be futile and dangerous to poor and near-poor who depend on it

docs.lead_paragraph: We already know that Wal-Mart is the biggest retailer. (If it were an independent nation, it would be China's eighth-largest trading partner.) We also know that it is maniacal about low prices. (Some economists say it has single-handedly cut inflation by 1 percent in recent years, saving consumers billions of dollars annually.) We know that its labor practices have come under attack. (It charges its workers so much for health insurance that about one-third of them do not have it.) But the more than 250 sociologists, anthropologists, historians and other scholars who gathered at the University of California here on Monday for a conference on Wal-Mart came looking for more than the company's vital statistics. Like archaeologists who pick over artifacts to understand an ancient society, the scholars here were examining Wal-Mart for insights into the very nature of American capitalist culture. As Susan Strasser, a history professor at the University of Delaware, said, ''Wal-Mart has come to represent something that's even bigger than it is.''

docs.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department moved on Thursday to shut down what it said was a health-benefits fraud that it said allowed employers nationwide to disguise wages by listing them as nontaxable reimbursement for medical costs or by deducting health insurance premiums improperly, costing the government both income and Social Security taxes. The government said that some 200 companies had taken part in two plans: Health Incentive and HealthIER, which were marketed by several interrelated companies, including TRG Marketing, Paradigm Solutions Group and Superior Solutions Group.

docs.lead_paragraph: As soon as 20,000 government workers went on strike two weeks ago, 70 Native Canadian hunters from Quebec took advantage of the absence of conservation officers and slaughtered dozens of caribou in an endangered herd in Labrador. The provincial government complained that the hunters had committed a crime against the environment. But it was only the most dramatic sign that many vital public services in this remote province of 525,000 people are beginning to break down. It also provided a cautionary tale for many other Canadian provinces that have been suffering growing budget deficits, debt burdens and tensions with public sector unions since the federal government began shifting many of the costs of social services their way in the mid-1990's.

docs.lead_paragraph: District Attorney Richard A. Brown announced the indictment of 36 people yesterday, including a reputed Bonanno crime family associate, who prosecutors say engineered a multimillion-dollar automobile insurance fraud. Those accused include five lawyers, three doctors, a dentist, a psychologist, a chiropractor, a physical therapist, an acupuncturist and an insurance company claims manager. Authorities said the scam involved staged accidents and fake victims who received unneeded treatments at a Richmond Hill medical clinic. Joseph Fratta, whom authorities identified as a reputed Bonanno associate, is accused of supervising the operation, and has been indicted on several charges, including enterprise corruption. Stacy Albin (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: The competition between public schools and private enterprise that the Bush administration is encouraging heated up the other day, just outside Classroom 207 at Wentworth Elementary School here. Over several months, a string of novice tutors from a private company offering federally financed after-school classes had tried and failed to control Room 207's dozen rambunctious students. A supervisor from the company was dispatched to troubleshoot. Effie McHenry, Wentworth's principal, was clucking her tongue in disapproval.

headline.main: For Children Being Left Behind, Private Tutors Face Rocky Start

docs.abstract: Private companies providing tutors for federally financed after-school classes under No Child Left Behind law are struggling with same discipline, attendance and other problems that have kept failing schools from raising proficiency levels on their own; vast start-up effort has proved chaotic in Chicago and many other districts; most companies pay tutors far below what public school teachers earn, making recruitment and retention of tutors difficult; low-income students at schools that fail for third year to meet annual targets on standardized tests are eligible for tutoring; some districts, including Chicago's, are organizing their own teachers to offer tutoring sessions alongside those offered by private companies; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERESA M. McGOVERN has never shied away from speaking her mind. But the death of her mother in the World Trade Center attack stunned her into silence. This public person became very private. Ms. McGovern is an assistant professor at the Columbia University Mailman School of Public Health, though she is best known as the founder of the H.I.V. Law Project, where for a decade she fought to change policies affecting women and poor people with AIDS. Now, she is snapping back. Wasn't that Ms. McGovern in Washington last week, seated just a few rows behind Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's national security adviser, at a hearing of the independent commission investigating the Sept. 11 attacks? It was. Ms. McGovern looked incredulous, tight-jawed, as Ms. Rice testified about the president's Aug. 6, 2001, daily briefing carrying the ominous title: ''Bin Laden Determined to Strike in U.S.''

headline.main: Activist Regaining Her Stride After 9/11 Loss
